Crimes.Crime_Name: Ministerial Relief Request under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Legal_Issue: Whether the principal applicant is entitled to a mandamus order regarding his pending request for ministerial relief
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), subsection 35(2)
Decision_Outcome: Mandamus order issued requiring the Minister to process the request and provide a decision within three months
Legal_Rule: Mandamus orders require unreasonable delay, public legal duty, and no other adequate remedy
Procedural_Issue: Standing, multiple mandamus orders contested by respondents
Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable delay in processing ministerial relief application submitted in 2008
Outcome_on_Merits: Granted in favor of the applicant
Key_Evidence_Considered: Draft recommendation ready by February 2010, expanding time estimates indicating delay
Legal_Framework: IRPA, judicial review principles, mandamus requirements
Applicant_Challenge: Delayed decision on ministerial relief despite eligibility and submission of application
Court_Result: Mandamus order issued; secondary applicant struck
Defendant_Response: Contested standing and argued against issuance of multiple mandamus orders
Remedy_Requested: Mandamus order to compel decision on ministerial relief
Remedy_Sought: Compel processing and decision on relief request
Resolution_Mechanism: Judicial review leading to court-ordered timeline
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Past involvement with designated regime in Haiti

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Violation_Type: Inadmissibility due to association with a designated foreign regime
Legal_Issue: Entitlement to mandamus order over delayed ministerial relief decision
Application_Facts: Principal applicant found inadmissible due to past role in Haitiâ€™s judiciary; applied for ministerial relief in 2008
Decision_Outcome: Delay deemed prima facie unreasonable; mandamus order issued
Remedy_Requested: Mandamus order to compel decision on ministerial relief
Court_Ruling: Granted mandamus for relief decision within three months; dismissed ancillary claims
Claimant_Status: Principal applicant denied permanent residence due to inadmissibility
Defendant_Behavior: Extended delays citing complex assessments and departmental reorganization
Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable delay in processing relief application without fault of applicant
Legal_Standard: Mandamus requires unreasonable delay, public duty, lack of alternative remedy
Assessment_Factor: Length of delay, government explanations, impact on applicant
Procedural_Issue: Standing, scope of judicial intervention in administrative processes
Evidence_Used: Timeline of application, draft recommendation, correspondence from counsel
Legal_Provision_Cited: IRPA provisions on inadmissibility and ministerial relief
Application_Basis: Request for permanent residence triggering admissibility assessment
Evidence_Assessed: Duration of delay, government responsiveness, procedural status
Relief_Sought: Compel decision on ministerial relief and permanent residence
Governing_Rule: IRPA rules on inadmissibility and discretionary relief
Outcome: Mandamus granted for ministerial relief; other claims dismissed
Harm_Assessment: Prolonged uncertainty affecting immigration status and family
Cause_Description: Inadmissibility based on historical association with Haitian regime led to relief request
Evidence_Handling: Consideration of procedural history and internal government timelines
Legal_Provision_Violated: None directly violated; failure to exercise discretion in timely manner
Residency_Compliance: Application for permanent residence interrupted by inadmissibility finding
Evidence_Assessment: Delay documented through official records and counsel submissions
Decision_Rationale: Three-year delay without justification constitutes unreasonable administrative inaction
Decision_Making_Body: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Legal_Standard_Applied: Prima facie unreasonableness of delay in administrative decision-making
